Which illum'd the ſaints face▪ and ran down apace,
Like the oil from Aaron's old beard, my brave boys.
The ſtrong nervous deer, with amazing career,
In ſwiftneſs he'd fairly run down;
And, like Sampſon, wou'd tear wolf, lion or bear.
Ne'er was ſuch a ſaint as our own, my brave boys.
When he'd run down a ſtag, he behind him wou'd lag;
For, ſo noble a ſoul had he!
He'd ſtop, tho' he loſt it, tradition reports it,
To give him freſh chance to get free, my brave boys.
With a mighty ſtrong arm, and a maſculine bow,
His arrow he drew to the head,
And as ſure as he ſhot, it was ever his lot,
His prey it fell inſtantly dead, my brave boys.
His table he ſp •• ad where the veniſon bled,
Be thankful, he uſed to ſay;
He'd laugh and he'd ſing, tho' a ſaint and a king,
And ſumptu • uſly dine on his prey, my brave boys.
Then over the h • lls, o'er the mountains and rills
He'd caper, ſuch was his delight;
And ne'er in his days, Indian hiſtory ſays,
Did lack a good ſupper at night, my brave boys.
On an old ſtump he ſat, without cap or hat,
When ſupper was ready to eat,
Snap ▪ his dog▪ he ſtood by, and caſt a ſheep's eye
For ven'ſon, the king of all meat, my brave boys.
Like Iſaac of old, and both caſt in one mould,
Tho' a wigwam was Tamm'ny's cottage,
He lov'd ſav'ry meat, ſuch that patriarch eat,
Of ven'ſon and ſquirre • made pottage, brave boys.
When fourſcore years old, as I've oft'times been told,
To doubt it, ſure, would not be right,
With a pipe in his jaw, he'd buſs his old ſquaw,
And get a young ſaint ev'ry night, my brave boys.
As old age came on, he grew blind, deaf and dumb,
Tho' his ſport, 'twere hard to keep from it,
Quite tired of life, bid adieu to his wife,
And blaz'd like the tail of a comet, brave boys.
What country on earth, then, did ever give birth
To ſuch a magnanimous ſaint?
His acts far excel all that hiſtory tell,
And language too feeble to paint, my brave boys.
Now, to finiſh my ſong, a full flowing bowl
I'll quaff, and ſing all the long day,
And with punch and wine paint my cheeks for my ſaint,
And hail ev'ry Firſt of ſweet May, my brave boys.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: What a ſeraphic voice! how it enlivens my ſoul! Come away, away, Roger, the moments are precious. Exeunt Dick and Roger.

div.head: SCENE VII. In a chamber, near BOSTON, the morning after the battle of BUNKER'S HILL.

sp.speaker: Clariſſa.
sp.p:
How lovely is this new-born day!—The ſun riſes with uncommon radiance after the moſt gloomy night my wearied eyes ever knew.—The voice of ſlumber was not heard—the angel of ſleep was fled— and the awful whiſpers of ſolemnity and ſilence prevented my eye-lids from cloſing.—No wonder—the terrors and ideas of yeſterday—ſuch a ſcene of war— of tumult—hurry and hubbub—of horror and deſtruction—the direful noiſe of conflict—the diſmal hiſſing of iron ſhot in vollies flying—ſuch bellowing of mortars—ſuch thund'ring of cannon—ſuch roaring of muſquetry—and ſuch claſhing of ſwords and bayonets—
ſuch cries of the wounded—and ſuch ſtreams of blood, ſuch a noiſe and cruſh of houſes, ſte • ples, and whole ſtreets of deſolate Charleſtown falling—pillars of fire, and the convulſed vortex of fiery flakes, rolling in flaming wreaths in the air, in dreadful combuſtion, ſeemed as tho' the elements and whole earth were envelop'd in one general, eternal conflagration and total ruin, and intermingled with black ſmoke, aſcending, on the wings of mourning, up to heaven, ſeemed piteouſly to implore the almighty interpoſition to put a ſtop to ſuch devaſtation, leſt the whole earth ſhould be unpeopled in the unatural conflict—Too, too much for female heroiſm to dwell upon—But what are all thoſe to the terrors that filled my affrighted imagination the laſt night?—Dreams—fances—evil bodings— ſhadows, phantoms and ghaſtly viſions continually hovering around my pillow, goading and harrowing my ſoul with the moſt terrific appearances, not imaginary, but real—Am I awake—Where are the Britiſh murderers?—where's my huſband?—my ſon?—my brother?— Something more than human tells me all is not well: If they are among the ſlain, 'tis impoſſible.—I—Oh! (She cries.)
sp.stage: Enter a neighbour, a ſpectator of the battle.
sp.p: Madam, grieve not ſo much.

sp.speaker: Clariſſa.
sp.p: Am I wont to grieve without a cauſe▪ Wou'd to God I did;—mock me not—What voice is that? methinks I know it—ſome angel ſent to comfort me?—welcome then. (She turns about) O, my neighbour, is it you? My friend, I have need of comfort. Haſt thou any for me?—ſay—will you not ſpeak? Where's my huſband?—my ſon? —my brother. Haſt thou ſeen them ſince the battle? Oh! bring me not unwelcome tidings. (Cries.)

sp.speaker: Neighbour.
sp.p: (Aſide. What ſhall I ſay?) Madam, I beheld them yeſterday from an eminence.

sp.speaker: Clariſſa.
sp.p: Upon that very eminence was I. What then?

sp.speaker: Neighbour.
sp.p: I ſaw the brave man Warren, your ſon and Brother.

sp.speaker: Clariſſa.
sp.p: What? O ye gods!—Speak on friend—ſtop, what ſaw ye?

sp.speaker: Neighbour.
sp.p: In the midſt of the tempeſt of war—

sp.speaker: Clariſſa.
sp.p: Where are they now?—That I ſaw too— What is all this?

sp.speaker: Neighbour.
sp.p: Madam, hear me—

sp.speaker: Clariſſa.
sp.p: Then ſay on—yet—O, his looks!—I fear!

sp.speaker: Neighbour.
sp.p: When General Putnam bid the vanguard open their front to the—

sp.speaker: Clariſſa.
sp.p: Oh, trifle not with me—dear Neighbour!— where ſhall I find them?—ſay—

sp.speaker: Neighbour.
sp.p: (Aſide. Heavens! muſt I tell her!) Madam, be patient—right and left, that all may ſee who hate us, we are prepared for them—

sp.speaker: Clariſſa.
sp.p: What then?—Can you find 'em?—

sp.speaker: Neighbour.
sp.p: I ſaw Warren and the other two heroes firm as Roxbury ſtand the ſhock of the enemy's fierceſt attacks, and twice put to flight their boaſted phalanx.

sp.speaker: Clariſſa.
sp.p: All that I ſaw, and more; ſay—wou'd they not come to me, were they well.

sp.speaker: Neighbour.
sp.p: Madam, hear me—

sp.speaker: Clariſſa.
sp.p: O! he will not ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Neighbour.
sp.p: The enemy return'd to the charge, and ſtumbling o'er the dead and wounded bodies of their friends, Warren received them with indiſſoluble firmneſs, and notwithſtanding their battalious aſpect, in the midſt of the battle, tho' ſurrounded with foes on ev'ry ſide—

sp.speaker: Clariſſa.
sp.p: O, my neighbour!—

sp.speaker: Neighbour
sp.p: Madam his nervous arm, like a giant refreſh'd with wine, hurl'd deſtruction where'er he came; breathing heroic ardour to advent'rous deeds, and long time in even ſcale the battle hung, 'till at laſt death turn'd pale and affrighted at the carnage—they ran—

sp.speaker: Clariſſa.
sp.p: Who ran?

sp.speaker: Neighbour.
sp.p: The enemy, Madam, gave way—

sp.speaker: Clariſſa.
sp.p: Warren never ran—yet—oh! I wou'd he had, I fear— (Cries.)

sp.speaker: Neighbour.
sp.p: I ſay not ſo, Madam.

sp.speaker: Clariſſa.
sp.p: What ſay ye then? he was no coward, neighbour.

sp.speaker: Neighbour
sp.p: Brave to the laſt. Aſide. I forgot myſelf.

sp.speaker: Clariſſa.
sp.p: What ſaid you? O Heavens! brave to the laſt! thoſe words—why do you keep me thus—cruel.

sp.speaker: Neigbbour.
sp.p: (Aſide. She will know it) I ſay, Madam, by ſome miſtaken orders on our ſide, the enemy rallied and return'd to the charge with freſh numbers, and your huſband, ſon and brother—Madam—

sp.speaker: Clariſſa.
sp.p: Stop!—O ye powers!—What?—ſay no more—yet let me hear—keep me not thus—tell me, I charge thee—

sp.speaker: Neighbour.
sp.p: (Aſide. I can hold no longer, ſhe muſt know it) Forgive me, Madam—I ſaw them fall—and Michael the arch-angel, who vanquiſh'd ſatan, is not more immortal than they.—) Aſide, Who can relate ſuch woes without a tear?)

sp.speaker: Clariſſa.
sp.p: Oh! I've heard enough—too—too much (Cries) yet—if thou haſt worſe to tell—ſay on—nought worſe can be—O ye gods!—cruel—cruel, thrice cruel— cou'd ye not leave me one— (She faints, and is caught by her friend, and placed in the chair, he rings the bell, the family come in, and endeavour to bring her too)

sp.speaker: Neighbour.
sp.p: With ſurpriſing fortitude ſhe heard the melancholy relation, until I came to the laſt cloſe— ſhe then gave me a mournful look, lifted up her eyes, and immediately ſunk motionleſs into my arms.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: Poor ſoul!—no wonder—how I ſympathize with her in her diſtreſs—my tender boſom can ſcarcely bear the ſight! A dreadful loſs! a moſt ſhocking ſcene it was, that brothers ſhould with brothers war, and in inteſtine fierce oppoſition meet, to ſeek the blood of each other, like dogs for a bare bone, who ſo oft in generous friendſhip and commerce join'd, in feſtivals of love and joy unanimous as the ſons of one kind and indulgent father, and ſeperately would freely in a good cauſe ſpend their blood and ſacrifice their lives for him.

sp.speaker: Neighbour.
sp.p:
A terrible black day it was, and ever will be remembered by New-England, when tha • vile Briton, (unworthy the name of a Briton) Lord Boſton, (curſe the name!) whoſe horrid murders ſtain American ſoil with blood; periſh his name! a fratricide!
'twas he who fir'd Charleſtown, and ſpread deſolation, fire, flames and ſmoke in ev • ry corner—he was the wretch, that waſter of the world, that licens'd robber, that blood ſtain'd inſulter of a free people, who bears the name of Lord Boſton, but from henceforth ſhall be called Cain, that pillag'd the ruins, and dragg'd and murder'd the infant, the aged and infirm. (But look ſhe recovers.)

sp.speaker: Clariſſa.
sp.p: O ye angels! ye cherubims and ſeraphims! waft their ſouls to bliſs, bathe their wounds with angelic balſam, and crown them with immortality. A faithful, loving and beloved huſband, a promiſing and filial ſon, a tender and affectionate brother: Alas! what a loſs—Whom have I now to comfort me?—What have I left, but the voice of lamentation: (She weeps) Ill fated bullets—theſe tears ſhall ſuſtain me—yes, ye dear friends! how gladly wou'd I follow you—but alas! I muſt ſtill endure tribulation and inquietudes, from which you are now exempt; I cannot ceaſe to weep, ye brave men, I will mourn your fall—weep on, flow mine eyes, and waſh away their blood, till the fountain of ſorrow is dried up—but, oh! it never— never will—my ſympathetic ſoul ſhall dwell on your boſoms, and floods of tears ſhall water your grave • ; and ſince all other comfort is deny'd me, deprive me not of the only conſolation left me of meditating on your virtues and dear memories, who fell in defence of liberty and your country—ye brave men—ye more than friends—ye martyrs to liberty!—This, this is all I aſk, 'till ſorrow overwhelm • me—I breathe my laſt; and ye yourſelves, your own bri • ht ſpirit, come and waft me to your peaceful abode, where the voice of lamentation is not heard, neither ſhall we know any more what it is to ſeperate.

lg.l: Eager the patriot meets his deſperate foe
With full intent to give the fatal blow;
The cauſe he fights for, animates him high,
His wife, his children and his liberty:
For theſe he conquers, or more bravely dies,
And yields himſelf a willing ſacrifice. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Near Norfolk, in Virginia, on board a man of war, Lord Kidnapper in the ſtate-room, a boat appears rowing towards the ſhip.

sp.speaker: Sailor.
sp.p: BOATSWAIN!

sp.speaker: Boatſwain.
sp.p: Holla.
Damn my eyes, Mr. Boatſwain, but here's a black flag of truce coming on board.

sp.speaker: Boatſwain.
sp.p: Sure enough—where are they from?

sp.speaker: Sailor.
sp.p: From Hell, I ſuppoſe—for they are as black as ſo many devils.

sp.speaker: Boatſwain.
sp.p: Very well—no matter—they're recruits for the Kidnapper.

sp.speaker: Sailor.
sp.p: We ſhall be all of a colour by and by—damn me.

sp.speaker: Boatſwain.
sp.p: I'll go and inform his Lordſhip and his pair of doxies of it, I ſuppoſe by this time they have trim'd their ſails, and he's done heaving the log.

sp.speaker: Boatſwain.
sp.p: Where's his Lordſhip?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: He's in the ſtate-room.

sp.speaker: Boatſwain.
sp.p: It's time for him to turn out, tell him I want to ſpeak to him.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: I dare not do it, Boatſwain! it's more than my life is worth.

sp.speaker: Boatſwain
sp.p: Damn your ſqueamiſh ſtomach, go directly, or I'll go myſelf.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: For God's ſake! Boatſwain—

sp.speaker: Boatſwain.
sp.p: Damn your eyes, you pimping ſon of a bitch, go this inſtant, or I'll ſtick my knife in your gammons.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: O Lord! Boatſwain. (Servant goes.)

sp.speaker: Boatſwain
sp.p:
(ſolus). What the devil—keep a pimp
guard here, better ſtation the ſon of a bitch at the maſt head, to keep a look out there, leſt Admiral Hopkins be upon us.
What's your will, Boatſwain.

sp.speaker: Boatſwain.
sp.p: I beg your Lordſhip's pardon, (Aſide. But you can ſoon fetch up Leeway, and ſpread the water ſail again) pleaſe your honour, here's a boat full of fine recruits along ſide for you.

sp.speaker: Kidnapper.
sp.p: Recruits, Boatſwain? you mean ſoldiers from Auguſtine, I imagine; what reg'mentals have they on?

sp.speaker: Boatſwain.
sp.p: Mourning, pleaſe your honour, and as black as our tarpawling.

sp.speaker: Kidnapper.
sp.p: Ha, ha, well, well, take 'em on board.

sp.speaker: Boatſwain.
sp.p: I'll be on deck preſently.

sp.speaker: Boatſwain.
sp.p: With ſubmiſſion to your honour, d'ye ſee (ſcratching his head) I think we have gallows-looking dogs enough on board already—the ſcrapings of Newgate, and the refuſe of Tyburn, and when the wind blows aft, damn 'em they ſtink like polecats—but d'ye ſee, as your honour pleaſes, with ſubmiſſion, if it's Lord Paramount's orders, why it muſt be ſo, I ſuppoſe—but I've done my duty, d'ye ſee—

sp.speaker: Kidnapper.
sp.p: Ha, ha, the work muſt be done, Boatſwain, no matter by whom.

sp.speaker: Boatſwain.
sp.p: Why, aye, that's true, pleaſe your honour, any port in a ſtorm—if a man is to be hang • d, or have his throat cut, d'ye ſee—who are ſo fit to do it as his own ſlaves? eſpecially as they're to have their freedoms for it; nobody can blame them, nor your honour neither, for you get them for half price, or nothing at all, d'ye ſee me, and that will help to leſſen poor Owld England's taxes, and when you have done with 'em here, and they get their brains knock'd out, d'ye ſee, your honour can ſell them in the Weſt-Indies, and that will be ſomething in your honor's pocket, d'ye ſee—well, ev'ry man to his trade—but, damn my impudence for all, I ſee your honour knows all about it—d'ye ſee. Exit Boatſwain.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Lord Kidnapper returns to his ſtate-room, the Boatſwain comes on deck and pipes.
div.p: All hands ahoi—hand a rope, ſome of you Tories, forward there, for his worſhip's regiment of black guards to come aboard.

sp.speaker: Boatſwain.
sp.p: Your humble ſervant, Gentlemen, I ſuppoſe you want to ſee Lord Kidnapper? Clear the gangway • here of them Tyburn tulips. Pleaſe to walk aft, brother ſoldiers, that's the fitteſt birth for you, the Kidnapper's in the ſtate room, he'll hoiſt his ſheet-anchor preſently, he'll be up in a jiffin—as ſoon as he has made faſt the end of his ſmall rope athwart Jenny Bluegarter and Kate Common's ſtern poſts.

sp.speaker: Firſt Sailor.
sp.p: Damn my eyes, but I ſuppoſe, meſsmate, we muſt bundle out of our hammocks this cold weather, to make room for theſe black regulars to ſtow in, tumble upon deck, and chooſe a ſoft birth among the Snow?

sp.speaker: Second Sailor.
sp.p: Blaſt 'em, if they come within a cable's length of my hammock, I'll kick them to hell thro' one of the gun ports.

sp.speaker: Boatſwain.
sp.p: Come, come, brothers, don't be angry, I ſuppoſe we ſhall ſoon be in a warmer latitude— the Kidnapper ſeems as fond of theſe black regulars (as you call 'em • ack) as he is of the brace of whores below; but as they come in ſo damn'd ſlow, I'll put him in the humour of ſending part of the fleet this winter to the coaſt of Guinea, and beat up for volunteers, there he'll get recruits enough for a hogſhead or two of New England rum, and a few old pipe-ſhanks, and ſave poor Owld-England the trouble and expence of cloathing them in the bargain.

sp.speaker: Firſt Sailor.
sp.p: Aye, Boatſwain, any voyage, ſo it's a warm one—if it's to hell itſelf—for I'm ſure the devil muſt be better off than we, if we are to ſtay here this winter.

sp.speaker: Second Sailor.
sp.p: Any voyage, ſo it's to the ſouthward, rather than ſtay here at lazy anchor—no fire, nothing to eat or drink, but ſuck our froſty fiſts like bears, unleſs we turn ſheep-ſtealers again, and get our brains knock'd out. Eigh, maſter cook, you're are a gentleman now—nothing to do—grown ſo proud, you wont ſpeak to poor folks, I ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: The devil may cook for 'em for me—if I had any thing to cook—a parcel of frozen half ſtarv'd dogs. I ſhou • d never be able to keep 'em out of the cook room, or their noſes out of the fluſh-tub.

sp.speaker: Boatſwain.
sp.p: Damn your old ſmoaky jaws, you're better off than any man on board, your trouble will be nothing,—for I ſuppoſe they'll be diſburſted in different meſſes among the Tories, and it's only putting on the big pot, kockey. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: What ſignifies, Mr. Boatſwain, the big pot or the little pot, if there's nothing to cook? no fire, coal or wood to cook with? Blaſt my eyes, Mr. Boatſwain, if I diſgreaſe my ſelf ſo much, I have had the honour, damn me (though I ſay it that ſhou'dn't ſay it) to be chief cook of a ſeventy-four gun ſhip, on board of which was Lord Abel-Marl and Admiral Poke kock.

sp.speaker: Boatſwain.
sp.p: Damn the lyars—old ſinge-the-devil— you chief cook of a ſeventy-four gun ſhip, eigh? you the devil, you're as proud as hell, for all you look as old as Matheg'lum, hand a pair of ſilk ſtockings for our cook here, d'ye ſee—laſh a handſpike athwart his arſe, get a ladle full of • luſh and a handful of brimſtone for his hair, and ſtep one of you Tories there for the devil's barber, to come and ſhave him and dreſs him. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: No, Mr. Boatſwain, it's not pride—but look'e (as I ſaid before) I'll not diſgreaſe my ſtation, I'll throw up my commiſſion, before I'll ſtand cook for a parcel of ſcape gallows, convict Tory dogs and run-away Negroes.

sp.speaker: Boatſwain.
sp.p:
What's that you ſay? Take care, old froſty face—What? do you accuſe his worſhip of turning kidnapper, and harbouring run away Negroes?—
Softly, or you'll be taken up for a Whig, and get a handſome coat of • luſh and hogs feathers for a chriſtmaſs-box, cockey: Throw up your commiſſion, eigh? throw up the pot-halliards, you mean, old piſs-to-windward? Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: I tell you, Mr. Boatſwain—I—

sp.speaker: Boatſwain.
sp.p: Come, come, give us a chaw of tobacco, Cook—blaſt your eyes, don't take any pride in what I ſay—I'm only joking, d'ye ſee—

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Well, but Mr. Boatſwain—

sp.speaker: Boatſwain.
sp.p: Come, avaſt, bel • y the lan • ards of your jaws, and let's have no more of it, d'ye ſee (Boatſwain pipes) Make faſt that boat along ſide there.

div.stage: Exeunt every man to his ſtation.

div.head: SCENE IV. Lord Kidnapper comes up on the quarter deck.
div.p: Well, my brave blacks, are you come to li • t?

sp.speaker: Cudjo.
sp.p: Eas, maſſa Lord, you preezee.

sp.speaker: Kidnapper.
sp.p: How many are there of you?

sp.speaker: Cudjo.
sp.p: Twenty-two, maſſa.

sp.speaker: Kidnapper.
sp.p: Very well, did you all run away from your maſters?

sp.speaker: Cudjo.
sp.p: Eas, maſſa Lord, eb'ry one, me too.

sp.speaker: Kidnapper.
sp.p: That's clever; they have no right to make you ſlaves, I wiſh all the Negroes wou'd do the ſame, I'll make 'em free—what part did you come from.

sp.speaker: Cudjo.
sp.p: Diſſe brack man, diſſe one, diſſe one, diſſe one, diſſe one, come from Hamton, diſſe one, diſſe one, diſſe one, come from Nawfok, me come from Nawfok too.

sp.speaker: Kidnapper.
sp.p: Very well, what was your maſter's name.

sp.speaker: Cudjo.
sp.p: Me maſſa name Cunny Tomſee.

sp.speaker: Kidnapper.
sp.p: Colonel Thompſon—eigh?

sp.speaker: Cudjo.
sp.p: Eas maſſa, Cunney Tomſee.

sp.speaker: Kidnapper.
sp.p: Well then I'll make you a major—and what's your name?

sp.speaker: Cudjo.
sp.p: Me maſſa cawra me Cudjo.

sp.speaker: Kidnapper.
sp.p: Cudjo?—very good was you ever chriſtened,

sp.speaker: Cudj.
sp.p: No, maſſa, me no criſſen.

sp.speaker: Kidnapper.
sp.p: Well then I'll chriſten you—you ſhall be called major Cudjo Thompſon, and if you behave well, I'll ſoon make you a greater man than your maſter, and if I find the reſt of you behave well, I'll make you all officers, and after you have ſerv'd Lord Paramount a while, you ſhall have money in your pockets, good cloaths on your backs, and be as free as them white men there. (Pointing forward to a parcel of Tories.)

sp.speaker: Cudjo.
sp.p: Tanka, maſſa, gaw breſſe, maſſa Kidnap.

sp.speaker: Sailor.
sp.p: (Aſide) What a damn'd big mouth that Cudjo h • s—as large as our main hatch-way—

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: (Aſide) Aye, he's come to a wrong place to make a good uſe of it—it might ſtand ſome little chance at a Lord Mayor's feaſt.—

sp.speaker: Kidnapper.
sp.p: Now go forward, give 'em ſomething to eat and drink there. Aſide. Poor devils, they look half ſtarved and naked like ourſelves

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: (Aſide) I don't know where the devil they'll get it; the ſight of that fellow's mouth is enough to breed a famine on board, if there was not one already.

sp.speaker: Sailor.
sp.p: Aye, he'd tumble plenty down his damn'd guts and ſwallow it, like Jones ſwallow'd the whale.

sp.speaker: Kidnapper.
sp.p: To-morrow you ſhall have guns like them white men- Can you ſhoot ſome of them rebels aſhore, Major Cudjo?

sp.speaker: Cudjo.
sp.p: Eas, maſſa, me try.

sp.speaker: Kidnapper.
sp.p: Wou'd you ſhoot your old maſter, the Colonel, if you could ſee him?

sp.speaker: Cudjo.
sp.p: Eas, maſſa, you terra me, me ſhoot him down dead.

sp.speaker: Kidnapper.
sp.p: That's a brave fellow—damn'em—down with them all—ſhoot all the damn'd rebels▪

sp.speaker: Serjeant.
sp.p: (Aſide.) Brave fellows indeed!

sp.speaker: Kidnapper.
sp.p: Serjeant!

sp.speaker: Serjeant.
sp.p: I wait your Lordſhip's commands.

sp.speaker: Kidnapper.
sp.p:
Serjeant, to morrow begin to teach thoſe black recruits the exerciſe, and when they have learn'd ſufficiently well to load and fire, then incorporate them
among the regulars and the other whites on board; we ſhall in a few days have ſome work for 'em, I expect— be as expeditions as poſſible. (Aſide to him.) Set a guard over them every night, and take their arms from them, for who knows but they may cut our throats.

sp.speaker: Serjeant.
sp.p: Very true, my Lord, I ſhall take particular care.

div.stage: Exit Kidnapper, Serjeant and Negroes walk farward.

sp.speaker: Serjeant.
sp.p: Damn'em, I'd rather ſee half their weight in beef.

sp.speaker: Boatſwain.
sp.p: Aye, curſe their ſtomacks, or mutton either; then our Cook wou'dn't be ſo damn'd lazy as he is, ſtrutting about the deck like a noble man, receiving Paramount's pay for nothing.

sp.speaker: Serjeant.
sp.p: Walk faſter, damn your black heads. I ſuppoſe, Boatſwain, when this hell-cat reg'ment's compleat, they'll be reviewed in Hyde park?—

sp.speaker: Boatſwain.
sp.p: Aye, blaſt my eyes, and our Chaplain with his dirty black gown, or our Cook, ſhall be their general, and review 'em, for he talks of throwing up his pot-halliards commiſſion, in hopes of it.

sp.speaker: Serjeant
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha —

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: I'd ſee the devil have 'em firſt.—

sp.speaker: Kidnapper.
sp.p: Theſe blacks are no ſmall acquiſition, them and the Tories we have on board, will ſtrengthen us vaſtly; the thoughts of emancipation will make 'em brave, and the encouragement given them by my proclamation, will greatly intimidate the rebels-internal enemies are worſe than open foes.—

sp.speaker: Chaplain.
sp.p: Very true, My Lord; David prayed that he might be preſerved from ſecret enemies.

sp.speaker: Kidnapper
sp.p: Aye, ſo I've heard, but I look upon this to be a grand manoeuvre in politics; this is making dog eat dog—thief ca • ch thief—the ſervant againſt his maſter—rebel againſt rebel—what think you of that, parſon?
A houſe divided thus againſt itſelf cannot ſtand, according to ſcripture—My Lord, your obſervation is truly ſcriptural.

sp.speaker: Kidnapper.
sp.p: Scripture? poh, poh—I've nothing to do with ſcripture—I mean politically, parſon.

sp.speaker: Chaplain.
sp.p: I know it very well; ſure, My Lord, I underſtand you perfectly.

sp.speaker: Kidnapper.
sp.p: Faith that's all I care for; if we can ſtand our ground this winter, and burn all their towns that are acc • ſſible to our ſhips, and Colonel Connolly ſucceeds in his plan, there's not the leaſt doubt but we ſhall have ſupplies from England▪ very early in the ſpring, which I have wrote for; then, in conjunction with Connolly, we ſhall be able to make a deſcent where we pleaſe, and drive the rebels like hogs in a pen.

sp.speaker: Chaplain.
sp.p: And then gather them (as the ſcripture ſay) as a hen gathereth her chickens.

sp.speaker: Kidnapper.
sp.p: True, Mr. Scripture.

sp.speaker: Captain Squires.
sp.p: Very good, but you muſt take care of the hawks.

sp.speaker: Kidnapper.
sp.p: What do you mean by the hawks, Captain?

sp.speaker: Captain Squires.
sp.p: I mean the ſhirt men, the riflemen, My Lord.

Aye, damn'em, hawks indeed; they are 〈◊〉 dogs; a man is never ſafe where they are, but I'll take care to be out of their reach, let others take their chance, for I ſee they have no reſpect to perſons— I ſuppoſe they wou'd ſhoot at me, if I were within th ••• reach.

sp.speaker: Chaplain.
sp.p: Undoubtedly, they would be more fond of you than of a wild tu • key, a parcel of ignorant 〈◊〉 mannerl • raſcals, they pay no more reſpect to a Lord than th • y wou'd to a devil.

sp.speaker: Kidnapper.
sp.p: The ſcound • els are grown ſo damn'd impudent too, that one can ſcarcely get a roaſting pig now a days, but I • ll be even with them by and by.

sp.speaker: Chaplain.
sp.p: I hope we ſhall get ſomething good for our Chriſtmas dinner—ſo much abſtinance and involuntary mortification, cannot be good for the ſoul—a war in the body corporal is of more dangerous conſequence than a civil war to the ſtate, or hereſy and ſchiſm to the church.

sp.speaker: Kidnapper.
sp.p: Very true, parſon—very true—now I like your doctrine—a full belly is better than an empty ſermon; preach ihat doctrine;—ſtick to that text, and you • ll not fail of making converts.

sp.speaker: Chaplain.
sp.p: The wiſeſt of men ſaid, there is nothing better, than that a man ſhould enjoy that which he hath, namely, eat, drink, and be merry, if he can.

sp.speaker: Kidnapper.
sp.p: You'r very right—Solomon was no fool, they ſay— (he ſings)

lg.l: Give me a charming laſs, Twangdill • cries,
I know no pleaſure, but love's ſweet joys.

sp.speaker: Chaplain.
sp.stage: (Sings. Give me the bottle, ſays the red face ſot. For a whore I'd not give ſix pence, not a groat.
sp.p: Yet two is better than one, my Lord, for the ſcriptures farther ſay, if one be alone, how can there be heat? you ſeem to be converted to that belief, for you have a brace of them, as the Boa ſwain ſays.

sp.speaker: Kidnapper.
sp.p: Ha, ha. It's a pity but you were a biſhop, you have the ſcriptures ſo pat— now I'll go and take a ſhort nap, mean while; Captain if any thing new happens, pray o • der my ſervant to wake me.

sp.speaker: Captain Squires.
sp.p: I will my Lord.

sp.speaker: Chaplain.
sp.p: And you and I'll crack a bottle, Captain; (bring a bottle, boy!) 'tis bad enongh to periſh by famine, but ten thousand times worſe to be choak'd for want of moiſture. His Lordſhip and two more makes three; and you and I and the bottle make three more, and a three fold cord is not eaſily broken; ſo we're even with them.

sp.speaker: Captain Squires.
sp.p: With all my heart.—Boy, bear a hand.
Coming, Sir.

sp.speaker: Chaplain.
sp.p: Tom, Tom! make haſte, you ſcoundrel! fetch two bottles. I thank we can manage it.

sp.speaker: Chaplain.
sp.p: That's right, Tom.—Now bring the glaſſes, and ſhut the door after you. Exit Tom.

div.head: SCENE VII. In BOSTON. A council of war after the battle of BUNKER's HILL.
div.stage: Lord Boſton, Admiral Tombſtone, Elbow Room, Mr. Caper, General Clinton, Earl Percy.

sp.speaker: Lord Boſton.
sp.p: I fully expected, with the help of the laſt reinforcement you brought me over, and the advise and aſſiſtance of three accompliſh'd and experienc'd Generals, I ſhould have been able to have ſubdued the rebels and gain'd immortal laurels to myſelf— have return'd to Old England like a Roman Conſul, with a ſcore or two of the rebel Generals, Colonels and Majors, to have grac'd my triumph.

sp.speaker: Elbow Room.
sp.p: You have been vaſtly diſappointed Sir— you muſt not look for laurels (unleſs wild ones) nor expect triumphs (unleſs ſham ones) from your own victories or conqueſts in America.

sp.speaker: Lord Boſton.
sp.p:
And yet not more diſappointed than you, Sir— witneſs your thraſonical ſpeeches on your firſt landing, provided you had but elbow room—and Mr. Caper to bring over Monſieur Rigadoon, the dancing maſter, and Signior Roſin the fiddler forſooth; he thought, no doubt, to have country danc'd the rebels out of their liberty with ſome of his new cuts— with his ſoft muſic to have faſcinated their wives and daughters, and with ſome of 'em, no doubt, to have taken the tower of America, with his reg'ment of fine ſleek prancing horſes, that have been feeding this ſix months on co • fiſh tails; he thought to have grown fat with feaſting, dancing, and drinking tea with the Ladies, inſtead of being the ſkeleton he now appears to
be— not to mention any thing of his letter, wherein he laments Tom's abſence; for See Burgoyne's letter
•
had Tom been with him (he ſays) he wou'd have been out of danger, and quite ſecure from the enemy's ſhot."

sp.speaker: Percy.
sp.p: I think, Gentlemen, we're even with you now; you have had your mirth and frolic with us, for dancing Yankee Doodle, as you call it, from Lexington —I find you have a ſeverer dance, a brave ſweat at Bunker's Hill, and have been obliged to pay the fiddler in the bargain.

sp.speaker: Clinton.
sp.p: However, Gentlemen, I approve (at proper ſeaſons) of a little joking, yet I can by no means think (as we have ſuch bad ſucceſs with our crackers) that this is a proper time to throw your ſquibs.

sp.speaker: Lord Boſton.
sp.p: I grant you, Sir, this is a very improper time for joking; for my part, I was only ſpeaking as to my own thoughts, when Mr. Elbow Room made remarks, which he might as well have ſpared.

sp.speaker: Elbow Room.
sp.p: I took you, Sir, as meaning a reflection upon us for our late great loſs, and particularly to myſelf, or expreſſing ſome ſurpriſe on our firſt landing, that you ſhould ſuffer a parcel of ignorant peaſants to drive you before 'em like ſheep from Lexington; and I muſt own I was a little chagrin'd at your ſeeming ſo unconcern'd at ſuch an affair as this, (which had nearly prov'd our ruin) by your inuendoes and ironacal talk of accompliſh'd Generals, Roman Conſuls and triumphs.

sp.speaker: Lord Boſton.
sp.p: My mentioning accompliſh'd Generals, ſurely, Sir, was rather a compliment to you.

sp.speaker: Elbow Room.
sp.p: When irony paſs current for compliments, and we take it ſo, I ſhall have no objection to it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Caper.
sp.p: The affair of Lexington, My Lord Boſton, at which you were ſo much affrighted (if I am rightly inform'd) was becauſe you then ſtood on your own bottom, this of Bunker's Hill you ſeem ſecretly to rejoice at, only becauſe you have three accompliſh'd and experienc'd Generals to ſhare the diſgrace with you, beſides the brave Admiral Tombſtone—you talk of dancing and fiddling, and yet you do neither, as I ſee.

sp.speaker: Lord Boſton.
sp.p: And pray, Sir, what did you do with the commiſſion, the poſt, the Duke of Grafton gave you, in lieu of your loſſes at Preſton election, and the expences of your trial at king's bench for a riot, which had emptied your pockets? -Why you ſold it—you ſold it, Sir— to raiſe caſh to gamble with.—

sp.speaker: Admiral Tombſtone.
sp.p: Damn it, don't let us kick up a duſt among ourſelves, to be laugh'd at ſore and aft— this is a hell of a council of war—though I believe it will turn out one before we've done— a ſcolding and quarrelling like a parcel of damn'd butter whores—I never heard two whores yet ſcold and quarrel, but they got to fighting at laſt.

sp.speaker: Clinton.
sp.p: Pray, Gentlemen, drop this diſcourſe, consider the honour of England is at ſtake, and our own ſafety depends upon this day's conſultation.

sp.speaker: Lord Boſton.
sp.p: 'Tis not for argument ſake—but the dignity of my ſtation requires others ſhould give up firſt.

sp.speaker: Elbow Room.
sp.p: Sir, I have done, leſt you ſhould alſo accuſe me of obſtructing the proceedings of the council of war.

sp.speaker: Mr. Caper.
sp.p: For the ſame reaſon I drop it now.

sp.speaker: Lord Boſton.
sp.p: Well, Gentlemen, what are we met here for?

sp.speaker: Admiral Tombſtone.
sp.p: Who the devil ſhou'd know, if you don't?—damn it, didn't you ſend for us?

sp.speaker: Lord Boſton.
sp.p: Our late great loſs of men has tore up the foundation of our plan, and render'd all further attempts impracticable—'twill be a long time ere we can expect any more reinforcements—and if they ſhould arrive, I'm doubtful of their ſucceſs.

sp.speaker: Clinton.
sp.p: The provincials are vaſtly ſtrong, and ſeem no novices in the art of war; 'tis true we gain'd the hill at laſt, but of what advantage is it to us?— none—the loſs of 1400 as brave men as Britain can boaſt of, is a melancholy conſideration, and muſt make our moſt ſanguinary friends in England abate of their vigour.

sp.speaker: Elbow Room.
sp.p:
I never ſaw nor r • ad of any battle equal to it—never was more martial courage diſplay'd,
and the provincials, to do the dogs juſtice, fought like heroes, fought indeed more like devils than men; ſuch carnage and deſtruction not exceeded by Blenheim, Mind • n, Fontenoy, Ramillies, Dittingen, the battle of the Boyne, and the late affair of the Spaniards and Algerin • s—a mere cock-fight to it—no laurels there.

sp.speaker: Mr Caper.
sp.p: No, nor triumphs neither—I regret in particular the number of brave Officers that fell that day, many of whom were of the firſt families in England.

sp.speaker: Admiral Tombſtone.
sp.p: Aye, a damn'd affair indeed— many powder'd beaus—petit maitres—fops—f • ibbles- ſkip jacks—macaronies—jack puddings—noblemen's baſtards and whores ſons fell that day—and my poor marines ſtood no more chance with 'em than a cat in hell without claws.

sp.speaker: Lord Boſton.
sp.p: It can't be help'd, Admiral; what is to be done next?

sp.speaker: Admiral Tombſtone.
sp.p: Done?—why, what the devil have you done?—nothing yet, but eat Paramount's beef, and ſteal a few Yankee ſheep—and that, it ſeems, is now become a damn'd louſy, beggarly trade too, for you hav'n't left yourſelves a mouthful to eat.

lg.l: (Aſide) "Bold at the council board,
"But cautious in the field, he ſhunn'd the ſword—'

sp.speaker: Lord Boſton.
sp.p: But what can we do, Admiral?

sp.speaker: Admiral Tombſtone.
sp.p: Do?—why ſuck your paws— that's all you're like to get. (Aſide) But av • ſt, I muſt bowſe taught there, or we ſhall get to logger heads ſoon, we're ſuch damn'd fighting fellows.

sp.speaker: Lord Boſton.
sp.p: We muſt act on the defenſive this winter, 'till reinforcements arrive.

sp.speaker: Admiral Tombſtone.
sp.p: Defenſive? aye, aye—if we can defend our bellies from hunger, and prevent a mutiny and civil war among the ſmall guts there this winter, we ſhall make a glorious campaign of it indeed—it will read well in the American Chronicles.

sp.speaker: Lord Boſton.
sp.p: I expect to be recalled this winter, when I ſhall lay the caſe before Lord Paramount, and let him know your deplorable ſituation.

sp.speaker: Admiral Tombſtone.
sp.p: Aye, do—and lay it behind him too; you've got the weather-gage of us this tack, meſsmate; but I wiſh you a good voyage for all—and don't forget to tell him, the poor worms are ſtarving too, having nothing to eat, but half ſtarv'd dead ſoldiers and the ſhips bottoms. (Aſide) A cunning old fox, he's gnaw'd his way handſomely out of the Boſton cage— but he'll never be a WOLFE, for all that.

sp.speaker: Mr. Caper.
sp.p: I ſhall deſire to be recalled too—I've not been us'd to ſuch fare—and not the leaſt diverſion or entertainment of any ſort going forward here—I neither can nor will put up with it.

sp.speaker: Admiral Tombſtone.
sp.p: I think we're all a parcel of damn'd boobies for coming three thouſand miles upon a wild gooſe chaſe—to periſh with cold—ſtarve with hunger—get our brains knock'd out, or be hang'd for ſheep-ſtealing and robbing hen-rooſts.

sp.speaker: Lord Boſton.
sp.p: I think, Admiral, you're always grumbling—never ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Admiral Tombſtone.
sp.p: Satisfied? I ſee no appearance of it—we have been here theſe twelve hours, ſcolding upon empty ſtomachs—you may call it a council of war, (and ſo it is indeed, a war with the guts) or what you will— but I call it a council of famine.

sp.speaker: Lord Boſton.
sp.p: As it's ſo late, Gentlemen, we'll adjourn the council of war 'till to-morrow at nine o'clock —I hope you'll all attend, and come to a concluſion.

sp.speaker: Admiral Tombſtone.
sp.p:
And I hope you'll then conclude to favour us with one of them fine turkeys you're keeping for your ſea ſtore, (aſide. or that fine, fat, black pig you or ſome of your guard ſtole out of the poor Negroe's pen) as it's near Chriſtmaſs, and you're going to make your exit—you know the old cuſtom among the ſailors—pave your way firſt—let us have one good dinner before we part, and leave us half a dozen pipes of Mr. Hancock's wine to drink your
health, and a good voyage, and don't let us part with dry lips.

lg.l: Such fooliſh councils, with no wiſdom fraught,
Muſt end in wordy words, and come to nought;
Juſt like St. James's, where they bluſter, ſcold,
They nothing know—yet they deſpiſe being told

div.head: SCENE I.

sp.speaker: General Preſcot.
sp.p: SO it ſeems indeed, one misfortune ſeldom comes alone—The rebels, after the taking of Ticonderoga and Chamdlee, as I juſt now learn by a Savage, marched immediately to beſiege St▪ John's, and are now before that place, cloſely inveſting it, and no doubt intend paying us a viſit ſoon.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: Say you ſo? then 'tis time to look about us.

sp.speaker: Gen. Preſcot.
sp.p: They'll find us prepar'd, I'll warrant 'em, to give 'em ſuch a reception as they little dream of—a parcel of Yankee dogs.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: Their ſucceſs, no doubt, has elated them, and given 'em hopes of conquering all Canada ſoon, if that's their intent.

sp.speaker: Gen. Preſcot.
sp.p: No doubt it is—but I'll check their career a little.—

div.stage: Enter Scouting Officer, with Colonel Allen, and other priſoners▪

sp.speaker: Scouting Officer.
sp.p: Sir, I make bold to preſent you with a few priſoners—they are a ſcouting detachment from the army beſieging St. John's.

sp.speaker: Gen. Preſcot.
sp.p: Priſoners? Rebels, I ſuppoſe, and ſcarcely worth hanging.

sp.speaker: Colonel Allen.
sp.p: Sir, you ſuppoſe wrong—you mean ſcarcely worth your while to attempt.

sp.speaker: Gen. Preſcot.
sp.p: Pray who are you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Col. Allen.
sp.p: A Man, Sir, who had the honour, 'till now, to command th • ſe brave men, whom you call rebels.

sp.speaker: Gen. Preſcot.
sp.p: What is your name? if I may be ſo bold?

sp.speaker: Col. Allen.
sp.p: Allen.

sp.speaker: Gen. Preſcot.
sp.p: Allen?

sp.speaker: Col. Allen.
sp.p: Yes, Allen.

sp.speaker: Gen. Preſcot.
sp.p: Are you that Allen, that Colonel Allen (as they call him) that dar'd to take Ticonderoga?

sp.speaker: Col. Allen.
sp.p: The ſame—the very man.

sp.speaker: Gen. Preſcot.
sp.p: Then rebels you are, and as ſuch I ſhall treat you, for daring to oppoſe Lord Paramount's troops, and the laws of the land.

sp.speaker: Col. Allen.
sp.p: Priſoners we are, 'tis true—but we deſpiſe the name of a rebel—With more propriety that name is applicable to your maſter—'tis he who attempts to deſtroy the laws of the land, not us—we mean to ſupport them, and defend our property againſt Paramount's and parliamentary tyranny.

sp.speaker: Gen. Preſcot.
sp.p: To anſwer you, were a poorneſs of ſpirit I deſpiſe; when Rebels dare accuſe, power that replies, forgets to puniſh; I am not to argue that point with you: And let me tell you, Sir, whoever you are, it now ill becomes you thus to talk—You'r my priſoner—your life is in my hands, and you ſhall ſuffer immediately—Guards! take them away.

sp.speaker: Col. Al • en.
sp.p: Cruel inſult!—pardon theſe brave men! what they have done has been by my orders—I am the only guilty perſon (if guilt there be) let me alone ſuffer for them all [opening his Brea • ] Here! take your revenge—Why do you heſitate?—Will you not ſtrike a breaſt that ne'er will flinch from your pointed bayone • s?

sp.speaker: Gen. Preſcot
sp.p: Provoke me not—Remember you are my priſoners?

sp.speaker: Col. Allen.
sp.p: Our ſouls are free!—Strike cowards, ſtrike!—I ſcorn to beg my life.

sp.speaker: Gen. Preſcot.
sp.p: Guards! away with them—I'll reſerve you for a more ignominious death—your fate is fix'd— away with them.

sp.speaker: Col. Allen.
sp.p: (Going off) Be glutted, ye thirſters after human blood—Come, ſee me ſuffer—mark my eye, and ſcorn me, if my expiring ſoul confeſſes fear—Come ſee and be taught virtue, and to die as a patriot for the wrongs of my country. Exeunt priſoners and guards.

sp.speaker: Col. Allen.
sp.p: What! ye infernal monſters! murder us in the dark?—What place is this?—Who reigns king of theſe gloomy manſions?—You might favour us at leaſt with one ſpark of light—Ye cannot ſee to do your buſineſs here.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: 'Tis our orders.

sp.speaker: Col. Allen.
sp.p: Ye dear, ye brave, wretched friends;— now wou'd I die for ye all—ye ſhare a death I would gladly excuſe you from—'Tis not death I fear—this is only bodily death—but to die noteleſs in the ſilent dark, is to die ſcorn'd, and ſhame our ſuff'ring country—we fall undignify'd by villains hands—a ſacrifice to Britain's outcaſt blood-hounds—This, this ſhakes the ſoul!— Come then, ye murderers, ſince it muſt be ſo—do your buſineſs ſpeedily—Farewell, my friends! to die with you is now my nobleſt claim, ſince to die for you was a choice deny'd—What are ye about?—Stand off, ye wretches!

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: I am order'd to lay you in irons (they ſeize him) you muſt ſubmit.

sp.speaker: Col. Allen.
sp.p:
What do you mean to torture us to death with chains, • acks and gibbets? rather diſp • tch us immediately—Ye executioners, ye inquiſitors, does this cruelty proceed from the lexity • ſhewed to the priſoners I took? D • d it offend you that I • reated them with friendſhip, generoſity, honour and humanity?—If it did, our ſuffrings
will redound more to our honour, and our fall be the more glorious—But remember, this fall will prove your own one day—Wretches! I fear you not, do your worſt; and while I lay ſuff'ring and chain'd on my back to the damp floor, • 'll yet pray for your converſion.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: Excuſe us, we have only obey'd our orders.

sp.speaker: Col. Allen.
sp.p: Then I forgive you; but pray execute them.

lg.l: Oh! my laſt friends! 'tis liberty, not breath,

Gives the brave life. Shu •
•• av • r • more than death,
He who ſpurns fear, and dares diſdain to be,
Mocks chains and wrongs— 〈…〉 for ever free▪
While the baſe coward, • h •• gh low,
Creeps but to ſuff'rings, and lives on for woe!

div.head: SCENE. III. In the camp at CAMBRIDGE.
div.stage: General Waſhington, General Lee, General Putnam.

sp.speaker: General Waſhington.
sp.p: Our accounts from the Northward, ſo far, are very favourable; Ticond •• oga, Chamblee, St. John • s and Montreal our troops are already in poſſeſſ • on of—and Colonel Arnold, having penetrated Canada, after ſuff'ring much thro' cold, fatigue, and want of proviſions, is now before Quebec, and General Montgommery, I underſtand, is in full march to join him, ſee theſe letters [they read]

sp.speaker: Gen. Lee.
sp.p: The brave, the intrepid Arnold, with his handful of fearleſs troops, have dar'd beyond the ſtrength of mortals—Their courage ſmil'd at doubts, and reſolutely march'd on, Clamb'ring (to all but themſelves) inſurmountable precipices, whoſe tops, covered with ice and ſnow, lay hid in the clouds, and dragging baggage, proviſions, ammunition and artillery along with them, by main ſtrength, in the dead of winter, over ſuch ſtupendous and amazing heights, ſeems almoſt incredible, unparallelled in history!—'Tis true, Hannibal's march over the Alps comes the neareſt to it—it was ſurpriſing undertaking, but when compar'd to this, appears but as a party of pleaſure, an agreeable walk, a ſabbath day's journey.

sp.speaker: Gen. Putman.
sp.p: Poſterity will ſtand amazed, and be aſtoniſh'd at the heroes of this new world, that the ſpirit of patriotiſm ſhould blaze to ſuch a height, and eclipſe all others, ſhould out brave fatigue, danger, pain, peril, famine, and even death itſelf, to ſerve their country; that they ſhould march, at this inclement ſeaſon, thro' long and dreary deſarts, thro' the remoteſt wilds, covered by the ſwamps and ſtanding lakes, beſet with trees, buſhes and briars, impervious to the • hearing rays of the ſun, where are no traces or veſtiges of human footſteps, wild untrodden paths, that ſtrike terror into the fierceſt of the brute creation.

lg.l: No bird of ſong to chear the gloomy deſert!
No animals of gentle love's enliven!

sp.speaker: Gen. Lee.
sp.p: Let Briton's do the like—no—they dare not attempt it—let them call forth the Hanoverian, the Heſſian, the hardy Ruſſian, or, if they will, the wild Coſſacks and Kalmucks of Tartary, and they would tremble at the thought! And who but Americans dare undertake it? The wond'ring moon and ſtars ſtood aloof, and turn'd pale at the ſight!

sp.speaker: Gen. Waſhington.
sp.p: I rejoice to hear the Canadians received them kindly, after their fatigue furniſhed them with the neceſſaries of life, and otherwiſe treated them very humanely—And the ſavages, whoſe hair ſtood an end, and look'd and liſten'd with horror and aſtoniſhment at the relation of the fatigues and perils they underwent, commiſerated them, and afforded all the ſuccour in ther power.

sp.speaker: Gen. Lee.
sp.p: The friendſhip of the Canadians and ſavages, or even their neutrality alone, are favourable circumſtances that cannot fail to hearten our men▪ and the junction of General Montgomery will inſpire 'em with freſh ardour.

sp.speaker: Gen. Putnam.
sp.p: Heavens proſper them!

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: Sir, here's an expreſs.

sp.speaker: Expreſs.
sp.p: I have letters to your Excellency.

sp.speaker: Gen. Waſhington.
sp.p: From whence?

sp.speaker: Expreſs.
sp.p: From Canada, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gen. Waſhington.
sp.p: From the Army?

sp.speaker: Expreſs.
sp.p: From the head-quarters, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gen. Waſhington.
sp.p: I hope matters go well there.— Had General Montgomery join'd Colonel Arnold when you lef • it?

sp.speaker: Expreſs.
sp.p: He had, Sir—theſe letters are from both thoſe gentlemen. [gives him the letters]

sp.speaker: Gen. Waſhington.
sp.p: Very well. You may now withdraw and refreſh yourſelf, unleſs you • ve further to ſay— I'll diſpatch you ſhortly.

sp.speaker: Expreſs.
sp.p: Nothing further, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gen. Waſhington.
sp.p: [Opens and reads the letters in General Lee and Putnam] I am well pleaſed with their contents— all but the behaviour of the haughty Carleton—to fire upon a flag of truce, hitherto unprecedented, even amongſt Savages or Algerines—his cruelty to the priſoners is cowardly, and perſonal ill treatment of General Montgomery is unbecoming a General—a Soldier—and beneath a Gentleman—and leaves an indelible mark of brutality—I hope General Montgomery, however, will not follow his example.

sp.speaker: General Lee.
sp.p: I hope ſo too, Sir—if it can be avoided; it's a diſgrace to the ſoldier, and a ſcandal to the Gentleman—ſo long as I have been a ſoldier, my experience has not furniſh'd me with a like inſtance.

sp.speaker: Gen. Putnam.
sp.p: I ſee no reaſon why he ſhou'dn't be paid in his own coin—If a man bruiſes my heel, I'll break his head —I cannot ſee the reaſon or propriety of bearing with their inſults—does he not know it's in our power to retaliate fourfo • d?

sp.speaker: Gen. Lee.
sp.p: Let's be good natur'd, General—let us ſee a little more of it firſt—

sp.speaker: Gen Putnam.
sp.p:
I think we have ſeen enough of it already for this twelve-months paſt. Methinks the behaviour of Lord Boſton, the ill treatment of poor Allen, to be thrown into a loathſome dungeon like a murderer,
be loaded with irons, and tranſported like a convict would ſufficiently rouſe us to a juſt retaliation—that imperious red coat, Carleton, ſhould be taught good manners—I hope to ſee him ere long in our College at Cambridge—

sp.speaker: Gen. Lee.
sp.p: I doubt; he'll be too cunning, and play truant—he has no notion of learning American manners; ev'ry dog muſt have his day (as the ſaying is); it may be our time by and by—the event of war is uncertain—

sp.speaker: Gen. Putnam.
sp.p: Very true, Sir, but don't let us be laugh'd at forever.
Sir, A Meſſenger this moment from Quebec, waits to be admitted.

sp.speaker: Gen. Waſhington.
sp.p: Let him enter. Exit Officer.

sp.speaker: Gen. Waſhington.
sp.p: What news bring you?

sp.speaker: Meſſenger.
sp.p: I am ſorry, Sir, to be the bearer of an unpleaſing tale—

sp.speaker: Gen. Waſhington.
sp.p: Bad news have you?— have you letters?

sp.speaker: Meſſenger.
sp.p: None, Sir, I came off at a moment's warning—my meſſage is verbal.

sp.speaker: Gen. Waſhington.
sp.p: Then relate what you know.

sp.speaker: Meſſenger.
sp.p: After the arrival and junction of General Montgomery's troops with Colonel Arnold's, Carlton was ſummoned to ſurrender; he diſdaining any anſwer, fir'd on the flag of truce—

sp.speaker: Gen. Waſhington.
sp.p: That we have heard—go on.

sp.speaker: Meſſenger.
sp.p:
The General finding no breach could be effected in any reaſonable time, their walls being vaſtly ſtrong, and his cannon rathet light, determined to attempt it by ſtorm—The enemy were apprized of it— however he paſſed the firſt barrier, and was attempting
the ſecond, where he was unfortunately killed, with ſeveral other brave Officers—

sp.speaker: Gen. Waſhington.
sp.p: Is General Montgomery killed?

sp.speaker: Meſſenger.
sp.p: He is certainly, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gen. Waſhington.
sp.p: I am ſorry for it—a brave man—I could wiſh him a better fate!—

sp.speaker: Gen. Lee.
sp.p: I lament the loſs of him—a reſolute ſoldier—

sp.speaker: Gen. Putnam
sp.p: Pity ſuch bravery ſhould prove unſucceſsful, ſuch merit unrewarded;—but the irreverſible decree of Providence!—who can gainſay?—we may lament the loſs of a friend, but 'tis irreligious to murmur at pre-ordination. What happened afterwards?

sp.speaker: Meſſenger.
sp.p: The Officer next in command, finding their attacks at that time unſucceſsful, retired in good order.

sp.speaker: Gen. Waſhington.
sp.p: What became of Colonel Arnold?

sp.speaker: Meſſenger.
sp.p: Col. Arnold, at the head of about three hundred and fifty brave troops, and Captain Lamb's company of artillery, having in the mean time paſſed through St. Rocques, attacked a battery, and carried it, tho' well defended, with the loſs of ſome men—

sp.speaker: Gen. Putnam.
sp.p: I hope they proved more ſucceſsful.

sp.speaker: Gen. Lee.
sp.p: Aye, let us hear.

sp.speaker: Meſſenger.
sp.p: The Colonel about this time received a wound in his l • g, and was obliged to crawl as well as he coud to the hoſpital, thro' the fire of the enemy, and wthin fifty yards of the walls, but, thro' Providence eſcap'd any further damage.—

sp.speaker: Gen. Putnam.
sp.p: Aye, providential indeed!

sp.speaker: Gen. Waſhington.
sp.p: Is he dangerouſly wounded?

sp.speaker: Meſſenger.
sp.p: I am told not, Si • .

sp.speaker: Gen. Waſhington.
sp.p: I am glad of it.—What follow'd?

sp.speaker: Meſſenger.
sp.p: His brave troops puſhed on to the ſecond barrier, and took poſſ • ſſion of it.

sp.speaker: Gen. Waſhington.
sp.p: Very good—proceed.

sp.speaker: Meſſenger.
sp.p:
A party of the enemy then fallying out from the palace-ga • e, attacked them in the • ear, whom they fought with incredible bravery for three hours,
and deeds of eternal fame were done; but being ſurrounded on all ſides, and overpowered by numbers, were at laſt obliged to ſubmit themſelves as priſoners of war.

sp.speaker: Gen. Putnam.
sp.p: Heav'ns! could any thing prove more unlucky? ſuch brave fellows deſerve better treatment than they'll get (I'm afraid) from the inhuman Carleton.

sp.speaker: Gen. Lee.
sp.p: Such is the fortune of war, and the viciſſitudes attending a military life; to-day conquerors, to-morrow priſoners.

sp.speaker: Gen. Waſhington.
sp.p: He dares not treat them ill—only as priſoners. Did you learn how thoſe brave fellows were treated?

sp.speaker: Meſſenger.
sp.p: It was currently reported in the camp they were treated very humanely.

sp.speaker: Gen. Waſhington.
sp.p: A change for the better.

sp.speaker: Gen. Putnam.
sp.p: Produc'd by fear no doubt from General Montgomery's letter—but no matter from what cauſe.

sp.speaker: Gen. Lee.
sp.p: How far did the remainder of the army retire?

sp.speaker: Meſſenger.
sp.p: About two miles from the city, where they are poſted very advantageouſly, continuing the blockade, and waiting for reinforcements.

sp.speaker: Gen. Lee.
sp.p: Did the enemy ſhew any peculiar marks of diſtinction to the corpſe of General Montgomery?

sp.speaker: Meſſenger.
sp.p: He was interred in Quebec, with every poſſible mark of diſtinction.

sp.speaker: Gen. Waſhington.
sp.p: What day did the affair happen on?

sp.speaker: Meſſenger.
sp.p: On the laſt day of the year.

sp.speaker: Gen. Waſhington.
sp.p: A remarkable day! When was the General interred?

sp.speaker: Meſſenger.
sp.p: The ſecond of January.

sp.speaker: Gen. Lee.
sp.p: What number of men in the whole attack was killed? did you learn?

sp.speaker: Meſſenger.
sp.p: About ſixty killed and wounded.

sp.speaker: Gen. Waſhington.
sp.p: Have you any thing further to communicate?

sp.speaker: Meſſenger.
sp.p: Nothing, Sir, but to inform you they are all in in good ſpirits, and deſire reinforcements and heavy artillery may be ſent them as ſoon as poſſible.

sp.speaker: Gen. Waſhington.
sp.p: That be our buſineſs—with all diſpatch. You may for the preſent withdraw. Serjeant!

sp.speaker: Serjeant.
sp.p: I wait your orders, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gen. Waſhington.
sp.p: See that the Meſſenger and his horſe want nothing.

sp.speaker: Serjeant.
sp.p: I ſhall, Sir. Exeunt Serjeant and Meſſenger.

sp.speaker: Gen. Waſhington
sp.p: I'll deſpatch an expreſs to the Congreſs. This repulſe, if I miſtake not, (or victory, as Carleton may call i • ) will ſtand them but in little ſt • ad—'twill be only a temporary reprieve— well reinforce our friends let the conſequence be what it may— Quebec muſt fall, and the lofty ſtrong walls and brazen gates (the ſhield of cowards) muſt tumble by an artificial earthquake; ſhould they continue in their obſtinacy, we'll arm our f • iends with miſſive thunders in their hands, and ſtream death on them ſwifter than the winds.

sp.speaker: Gen Lee.
sp.p: I lament the loſs of the valiant Montgomery and his brave officers and ſoldiers (a • this time more eſpecially) 'tis the fortune of war, 'tis unavoidable; yet, I doubt not, out of their aſhes will ariſe new heroes.

sp.speaker: Gen. Putnam.
sp.p: Who can die a more glorious, a more honorable death than in their country's cauſe?—let it redouble ou • a • dour, and kindle a noble emulation in our breaſts—let each American be determined to conquer or die in a righteous cauſe.

sp.speaker: Gen. Waſhington.
sp.p: I have drawn my ſword, and never will I ſh • ath it, 'till America is free, or I'm no more

sp.speaker: Gen. Lee.
sp.p:
Peace is deſpaired of, and who can think
of ſubmiſſion? The laſt petition from the Congreſs,like the former, has been diſregarded; they prayed but for liberty, peace and ſafety, and their omnipotent authoritative ſupremeſhips will grant them neither: War, then, war open and underſtood, muſt be reſolved on; this, this will humble their pride, will bring their tyrant noſes to the ground, teach 'em humility, and force them to hearken to reaſon when 'tis too late. My noble General, I join you [drawing his ſword] I'll away with the ſcabbard, and ſheath my ſword in the boſom of tyranny.

sp.speaker: Gen. Putnam.
sp.p: Have you not read the ſpeech, where frowning revenge and ſounds of awful dread for diſgrace at Lexington and loſs at Bunker's-hill echo forth? Not ſmiling peace, or pity, tame his ſullen ſoul; but, Pharaoh-like, on the wings of tyranny he rides and forfeits happineſs to feaſts revenge, 'till the waters of the red ſea of blood deluge the tyrant, with his mixed hoſt of vile cut-throats, murderers, and bloody butchers.

sp.speaker: Gen. Waſhington.
sp.p: Yet, finding they cannot conquer us, gladly would they make it up by a voluntary free will offering of a million of money in bribes, rather than be obliged to reliſh the thoughts of ſacrificing their curſed pride and falſe honour, they ſending over to amuſe us (to put us off our guard) a ſcore or two of commiſſioners with ſham negotiations in great ſtate, to endeavour to effect, by bribery, deception and chicanery, what they cannot accompliſh by force. Periſh ſuch wretches!—deteſted be their ſchemes!—Periſh ſuch monſters!—a reproach to human underſtanding—their vaunted boaſts and threats will vaniſh like ſmoke, and be no more than like ſnow falling on the moiſt ground, melt in ſilence, and waſte away—Blaſted, forever blaſted be the hand of the villainous traitor that receives their gold upon ſuch terms—may he become leprous, like Naaman, the Syrian, yea, rather like Gehazi, the ſervant of Eliſha, that it may ſtick to him for ever.

sp.speaker: Gen. Putnam.
sp.p: I join you both, and ſwear by all the heroes of New-England, that this arm, tho' fourſcore and four [drawing his ſword] ſtill nervous and ſtrong, ſhall wield this ſword to the laſt in the ſupport of liberty and my country, revenge the inſult offer'd to the immortal Montgomery, and brutal treatment of the brave Allen.

lg.l: Oh, liberty! thou ſun-ſhine of the heart!
Thou ſmile of nature, and thou ſoul of art!
Without thy aid no human hope cou'd grow,
And all we cou'd enjoy were turn'd to woe.

div.head: THE EPILOGUE.
div.l: SINCE tyrants reign, and luſt and lux'ry rule;
Since kings turn Nero's—ſtateſmen play the fool▪
Since parli'ment in curſed league combine,
To ſport with rights that's ſacred and divine;
Deſtroying towns with direful conflagration,
And murder ſubjects without provocation!
Theſe are but part of evils we could name,
Not to their glory, but eternal ſhame.
Petitions—waſte paper—great Pharaoh cries,
Nor care a ruſh for your remonſtrances.
Each Jacobite, and ev'ry pimping Tory,
Waits for your wealth, to raiſe his future glory:
Or penſions ſure, muſt ev'ry raſcal have,
Who ſtrove his might, to make FREEMAN a ſlave.
Since this the caſe, to whom for ſuccour cry?
To God • our ſwords, and ſons of liberty!
Caſt off the idol god!—kings are but vain!
Let juſtice rule, and independence reign.
Are ye not men? Pray who made men, but God?
Yet men make kings—to tremble at their nod!
What nonſenſe this—let's wrong with right oppoſe,
Since nought will do, but ſound, impartial blows.
Let's act in earneſt, not with vain pretence,
Adopt the language of ſound COMMON SENSE,
And with one voice proclaim INDEPENDENCE.
Convince your foes you will defend your right,
That b •• ws and k • ocks is all they will get by't.
Let tyrants ſee that you are well prepar'd,
By proclamations, ſword, nor ſpeeches ſcar'd;
Tha • liberty freeborn breathe in each ſoul!
One god-like union animate the whole!
